questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents with a lifelong pattern of social withdrawal. He avoids social interactions, prefers to be alone, and shows no interest in forming close relationships. He appears emotionally distant and indifferent to praise or criticism. On examination, there are no signs of psychosis, delusions, or hallucinations. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Schizoid Personality Disorder

Explanation:

Schizoid Personality Disorder: Characterized by lifelong social withdrawal, emotional coldness, and lack of desire for social relationships. This patient fits the classic presentation with no psychosis or interest in forming close relationships.

Personality disorder: An enduring pattern of inner experience and behavior that deviates markedly from the expectations of the individual’s culture

  • Pervasive and inflexible
  • Onset in adolescence or early adult- hood
  • Stable over time
  • Ego-syntonic (i.e., acceptable to the ego)
  • Leads to distress or impairment

DSM-5 divides the disorders into three categories, or clusters: A, B, and C.

Cluster A Personality Disorders

Cluster A personality disorders are characterized by odd and aloof behavior, prone to develop psychosis. They include:

  • Paranoid Personality Disorder
  • Schizoid Personality Disorder
  • Schizotypal Personality Disorder

Disorder

Key Features

Diagnosis

Treatment

Paranoid Personality Disorder (Option C ruled out)
  • Pervasive distrust and suspiciousness of others
  • Hostility, irritability, anger
  • Difficulty with trust and intimacy
  • Cynical view of world
  • No fixed delusions (vs. delusional disorder)
  • No hallucinations or formal thought disorder (vs. schizophrenia)
  • No tumultuous relationships (vs. borderline personality disorder)
  • No history of antisocial behavior (vs. antisocial personality disorder)
  • Psychotherapy: Straightforward and honest therapist, avoid warmth or deep interpretation
  • Group therapy: Helpful for some, but poorly tolerated
  • Behavior therapy: Social skills training, may feel intrusive

Schizoid Personality Disorder (Option B)
  • Lifelong social withdrawal
  • Eccentric, isolated, and lonely
  • Introverted with a bland affect
  • No psychotic symptoms (vs. schizophrenia, delusional disorder)
  • More withdrawn and aloof (vs. paranoid personality disorder)
  • No dysphoric loneliness
  • Fewer past relationships, possible autistic reverie
  • No desire for social interaction (vs. avoidant personality disorder)
  • Psychotherapy: Build trust, encourage expression
  • Group therapy: May benefit, initial silence likely
  • Pharmacotherapy: Limited evidence, medications for specific symptoms (e.g., emotional detachment)

Schizotypal Personality Disorder (Option A ruled out)
  • Social difficulties
  • Eccentric behavior and thinking (“magical thinking”)
  • Peculiar speech, superstitious beliefs, perceptual illusions
  • Odd behavior, thinking, and perception (vs. schizoid and avoidant personality disorders)
  • Differentiated from autism by the severity of language disorder
  • Lacks psychosis, or it's brief (vs. schizophrenia)
  • No odd behavior (vs. paranoid personality disorder)
  • Psychotherapy: Sensitive approach to avoid ridicule
  • Antipsychotics: Manage illusions and odd ideas
  • Antidepressants: Used for depressive symptoms

Avoidant Personality Disorder (Option D): Involves social withdrawal due to fear of rejection, but those individuals still desire social connections, unlike schizoid personality disorder (Cluster C Personality Disorder).

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is brought to therapy by his partner, who is frustrated with his constant need for admiration and his belief that he deserves special treatment. He frequently exaggerates his achievements and often feels that others are envious of him. Which type of personality disorder is he most likely exhibiting?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Narcissistic Personality Disorder

Explanation:

  • The patient exhibits a pervasive pattern of grandiosity, a strong need for admiration, and a sense of entitlement.
  • These traits include exaggerating achievements and believing that others are envious, which are hallmark features of Narcissistic Personality Disorder disorder.

Cluster B Personality Disorders:

  • Cluster B disorders are characterized by dramatic, impulsive, exploitative, and erratic behaviors. The disorders include:
    • Antisocial Personality Disorder (ASPD)
    • Borderline Personality Disorder (BPD)
    • Histrionic Personality Disorder (HPD)
    • Narcissistic Personality Disorder (NPD)

 

  • Cluster B Personality Disorders:

Disorder

Definition

Key Characteristics

Treatment Options

Antisocial Personality Disorder (ASPD) (Option A ruled out)

Disregard for the rights of others since age 15 (<15 years- “Conduct Disorder”)
  • Disregard legal and social rules, history of lying, manipulation, lack of remorse, criminality, impulsivity, irritable/ aggressive
  • Charming demeanor
  • H/o substance use
  • Psychotherapy: Contingency management.
  • Pharmacotherapy: Anticonvulsants, β-blockers, lithium, antipsychotics.

Borderline Personality Disorder (BPD) (Option B ruled out)

Instability in relationships, unstable self-image, and emotions; marked impulsivity.
  • Tumultuous relationships, identity diffusion, mood swings, impulsivity,
  • Fear of abandonment.
  • Feeling empty inside h/o suicidal attempts.
  • M/C in females.
  • Psychotherapy: DBT, MBT, TFP*
  • Pharmacotherapy: Antipsychotics, antidepressants. (avoid benzodiazepines)

Histrionic Personality Disorder (HPD) (Option C ruled out)

Excessive emotionality and attention-seeking behavior.

Strong need for attention, exaggerated emotions, shallow relationships.
  • Psychotherapy: Psychoanalytically oriented therapy.
  • Pharmacotherapy: Antidepressants, antianxiety agents, antipsychotics.

Narcissistic Personality Disorder (NPD)

Pattern of grandiosity, need for admiration, and lack of empathy

Exaggerated self-importance, craving admiration, lack of empathy, sense of entitlement, poor tolerance to criticism, fantasies of unlimited power/ success
  • Psychotherapy: Individual and group therapy
  • Pharmacotherapy: Lithium for mood swings, antidepressants

*DBT- Dialectical behavior therapy

*MDT- Mentalization-based therapy

*TFP- Transference-focussed psychotherapy

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman with a history of self-harm, chronic emptiness, and unstable relationships often alternates between idealizing and devaluing others. What defense mechanism is most commonly observed in this disorder?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Splitting

Explanation:

  • Splitting is a common defense mechanism in borderline personality disorder, where individuals view people or situations as either all good or all bad, contributing to their unstable relationships.

 

BORDERLINE PERSONALITY DISORDER:

 

General Characteristics

  • More common in females than in males.
  • Persons with BPD are often in a state of crisis, with frequent mood swings, shifting from being argumentative to depressed, and later feeling numb.
  • They can experience short-lived psychotic episodes and their behavior is highly unpredictable,

 

Self-Destructive Behaviors

  • Repetitive self-destructive acts such as wrist slashing or self-mutilation, often to elicit help from others, express anger, or numb overwhelming emotions.

 

Interpersonal Relationships

  • Individuals with BPD have tumultuous interpersonal relationships, feeling both dependent on others and hostile toward them when frustrated.
  • They cannot tolerate being alone and prefer companionship, even in unhealthy relationships.

 

Identity and Emotional Experience

  • Chronic feelings of emptiness, boredom, and a lack of a consistent sense of identity (identity diffusion) are common, with some complaining of feeling depressed despite fluctuating moods.

 

Distorted Relationships

  • Relationships are distorted, with others seen as either "all good" or "all bad" due to splitting, leading to idealization or devaluation of people.

 

Defense Mechanism

  • Projective identification is a common defense mechanism, where patients project unacceptable aspects of themselves onto others, inducing them to play the projected role.

 

Treatment

  • Dialectical behaviour therapy.
  • Mentalization based therapy.
  • Transference: Focussed Psychotherapy.
  • Pharmacotherapy: Antipsychotics, antidepressants, mood stabilizers like carbamazepine.

 

Sublimation (Option A) is a mature defense mechanism where individuals redirect unacceptable impulses or emotions into socially acceptable behaviors or activities.

Rationalization (Option C) involves explaining away or justifying behaviors or feelings to make them seem more acceptable or less distressing.

Displacement (Option D) involves shifting emotions from a threatening target to a safer one, such as expressing anger toward a friend instead of an authority figure.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with intense fear of rejection, leading her to avoid social interactions despite desiring close relationships. She often misinterprets others' comments as negative and feels timid and lacking in self-confidence. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Avoidant Personality Disorder

Explanation:

  • Avoidant Personality Disorder is characterized by hypersensitivity to rejection, a desire for close relationships, and avoidance due to fear of criticism or negative evaluation. This aligns with the patient’s symptoms.

Cluster C Personality Disorders

  • Characteristics: Cluster C personality disorders are characterized by anxious and fearful features and include:
    • Avoidant Personality Disorder
    • Dependent Personality Disorder
    • Obsessive-Compulsive Personality Disorder

Cluster C personality disorders:

Cluster C Personality Disorders

Characteristics

Diagnosis

Treatment

Avoidant/ Anxious Personality Disorder
  • Hypersensitivity to rejection
  • Desires close relationships but avoids them due to fear of rejection or criticism
  • Timid and lacks self-confidence
  • Misinterprets others’ comments negatively
  • Differentiate from:
  • Social Anxiety Disorder: Avoidance of specific situations
  • Panic Disorder with Agoraphobia: Avoidance develops after panic attacks
  • Schizoid Personality Disorder: Desires social interaction unlike those with schizoid disorder.
  • Psychotherapy:
  • Build a strong therapeutic alliance
  • Encourage gradual risk-taking in social situations
  • Group therapy for understanding social fears
  • Assertiveness training for better self-expression and self-esteem
  • Pharmacotherapy:
  • Beta-adrenergic antagonists like atenolol
  • Serotonergic agents like SSRI

Dependent Personality Disorder (Option A ruled out)
  • Pervasive dependent and submissive behavior
  • Difficulty making decisions without reassurance
  • Avoids responsibility
  • Fears being alone; may tolerate abusive relationships for connection
  • Differentiate from:
  • Histrionic Personality Disorder: More manipulative and often involved in short-term relationships
  • Borderline Personality Disorder: More unstable relationships.
  • Psychotherapy: Insight oriented therapy, behavior therapy, assertiveness training, family therapy and group therapy are also found useful.
  • Pharmacotherapy: Symptomatic management such as antidepressants.

Obsessive- Compulsive Personality Disorder (Option C ruled out)
  • Preoccupation with orderliness, perfectionism, and control
  • Rigid and inflexible
  • Difficulty relaxing
  • Highly devoted to work, often neglecting relationships
  • Differentiate from:
  • Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD): Symptoms are less severe and time-consuming in OCPD.
  • Ego- syntonic in OCPD vs ego- dystonic in OCD
  • Diagnosis is reserved for those with significant occupational or social impairment.
  • Psychotherapy:
  • Cognitive therapy or cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT)
  • Interpersonal psychotherapy may help with depressive symptoms
  • Pharmacotherapy: Limited evidence; some studies suggest benefits from fluvoxamine and carbamazepine. Citalopram may help with comorbid depression.

Social Anxiety Disorder (Option D) primarily involves anxiety in specific social situations, not a general avoidance of social contact as seen in avoidant personality disorder.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with episodes of sudden aggression, leading to property destruction and physical assaults. He reports feeling intense tension before these outbursts and experiences significant guilt and remorse afterward. Which of the following impulse control disorders is most likely affecting him?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Intermittent Explosive Disorder

Explanation:

  • Intermittent Explosive Disorder is marked by episodes of uncontrolled aggression with significant tension before the outbursts and feelings of guilt afterward.

Impulse Control Disorders

  • Definition: Conditions marked by an inability to resist strong urges to engage in harmful actions toward oneself or others.
  • Characteristics:
    • Tension and arousal before the act.
    • Gratification and relief post-act.
    • Followed by remorse, guilt, and secrecy, often delaying treatment.

Examples of Impulse Control Disorders:

Disorder

Description

Intermittent Explosive Disorder (Option C)
  • Episodes of uncontrolled aggression leading to assaults or property damage.
  • Aggression is disproportionate to triggers; episodes are followed by regret.
  • Important to rule out other causes.

Kleptomania (Option A ruled out)
  • Recurring urge to steal unnecessary items, with gratification derived from the act.
  • Guilt or anxiety may follow, but not anger or revenge.
  • Most shoplifters do not have kleptomania.

Pyromania (Option B ruled out)
  • Repeated deliberate fire-setting, accompanied by an urge and a sense of relief.
  • Individuals may show no remorse or concern for consequences.

Comorbidity of Impulse Control Disorders:

Disorder

Common Comorbid Conditions

Intermittent Explosive Disorder
  • Often co-occurs with substance use disorders, mood disorders, anxiety disorders, personality disorders, PTSD, and eating disorders.
  • Increased risk of self-harm.

Kleptomania
  • Frequently comorbid with major depressive disorder, anxiety disorders, other impulse control disorders, eating disorders, personality disorders, OCD, and substance use disorders.
  • Increased suicide risk.

Pyromania
  • Often associated with substance use disorders, mood disorders (depressive and bipolar), and other impulse control disorders.
  • Increased suicidal thoughts reported.

Treatment Approaches

Disorder

Recommended Treatments

Intermittent Explosive Disorder
  • Focus on recognizing warning signs and developing coping mechanisms.
  • Effective therapies include CBT and family therapy.
  • Medications: anticonvulsants, lithium, SSRIs.
  • Best chances of success: combination of medication and psychotherapy.

Kleptomania
  • Insight-oriented psychotherapy, psychoanalysis, CBT, and behavioral therapies (e.g., systematic desensitization).
  • Medications: SSRIs, tricyclic antidepressants, lithium, naltrexone.

Pyromania
  • Treatment is challenging; CBT is the most promising approach.
  • Family therapy is essential for youth.
  • Limited medication options; potential benefits from SSRIs, lithium, naltrexone.

Impulsive vs. Compulsive Disorders

  • Impulsive Behaviors: Driven by an urge, associated with pleasure or gratification.
  • Compulsive Behaviors: Driven by compulsion to relieve anxiety or distress; may not be enjoyable. (Option D ruled out)

Examples:

  • Kleptomania: Stealing for gratification.
  • Hoarding Disorder: Acquiring possessions due to anxiety about discarding them.

Role of Temperament in Impulse Control Disorders

  • Novelty Seeking: Impulsive and easily bored; may engage in risky behaviors for excitement (Eg. Likely to develop gambling disorder.).
  • Harm Avoidance: Anxious and sensitive to punishment; may act impulsively to escape negative emotions (Eg. May develop kleptomania to relieve anxiety).

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents to the clinic, expressing concern over his frequent and uncontrollable urges to engage in sexual activities. He reports spending several hours per day on sexual pursuits, such as browsing explicit material and seeking multiple sexual partners. Despite attempts to limit his behavior, he continues to act out sexually, leading to significant distress and disruption in his work and personal relationships. He has no history of substance abuse or mood disorders. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Compulsive sexual behavior disorder

Explanation:

  • The patient’s report of spending several hours per day on sexual pursuits, despite efforts to limit these behaviours, fits the diagnosis of Compulsive sexual behavior disorder.

 

Compulsive sexual behavior disorder:

  • Included under impulse control disorders in ICD-11.
  • Characterised by persistent failure to control intense, repetitive, sexual impulses resulting in repetitive sexual behaviours.
  • The repetitive sexual activity becomes the focus of life and results in adverse life consequences.

 

Bipolar disorder with hypersexuality (Option B):

  • While hypersexuality can occur during manic episodes of bipolar disorder, this patient's symptoms are not clearly linked to mood fluctuations.
  • Additionally, the patient’s behavior persists consistently, not only during periods of mania.

Borderline personality disorder (Option C):

  • The patient’s symptoms in this case are more consistent with an isolated compulsive behavior rather than the broader emotional and relational instability characteristic of BPD.

Sexual aversion disorder (Option D):

  • It involves the avoidance of sexual contact and a lack of interest related to sexual activity.
  • In contrast, compulsive sexual behavior disorder involves uncontrollable sexual urges or behaviors that cause distress and impairment, as seen in this case.
